fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a type and let {X}\xrightarrow {{f}}{Y} be a homomorphism of A-algebras. Assuming function extensionality, the type \mathchoice {\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g\colon X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g\colon X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g\colon X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g\colon X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}g\sim f of homomorphisms homotopic to f is contractible.

We expand the dependent sum \mathchoice {\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g\colon X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g\colon X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g\colon X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g\colon X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}g\sim f as a flat record telescope:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {bmatrix*}[l] {\mathopen {}\left \lvert g\right \rvert \mathclose {}} &\colon &{\mathopen {}\left \lvert X\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\to {\mathopen {}\left \lvert Y\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\\ \alpha _g &\colon &{\mathopen {}\left \lvert g\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\circ \alpha _X \sim \alpha _Y\\ {\mathopen {}\left \lvert H\right \rvert \mathclose {}} &\colon &{\mathopen {}\left \lvert f\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\sim {\mathopen {}\left \lvert g\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\\ \alpha _H &\colon &\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}} {\mathopen {}\left \lvert H\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\alpha _X a\cdot \alpha _g a = \alpha _f a \end {bmatrix*}
fr:mainmatter.html:p: First we re-order the telescope:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {bmatrix*}[l] {\mathopen {}\left \lvert g\right \rvert \mathclose {}} &\colon &{\mathopen {}\left \lvert X\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\to {\mathopen {}\left \lvert Y\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\\ {\mathopen {}\left \lvert H\right \rvert \mathclose {}} &\colon &{\mathopen {}\left \lvert f\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\sim {\mathopen {}\left \lvert g\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\\ \alpha _g &\colon &{\mathopen {}\left \lvert g\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\circ \alpha _X \sim \alpha _Y\\ \alpha _H &\colon &\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}} {\mathopen {}\left \lvert H\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\alpha _X a\cdot \alpha _g a = \alpha _f a \end {bmatrix*}
fr:mainmatter.html:p: By homotopy induction (function extensionality), the first two fields contract to a point with substitution {\mathopen {}\left [{\mathopen {}\left \lvert g\right \rvert \mathclose {}}:\equiv {\mathopen {}\left \lvert f\right \rvert \mathclose {}}; {\mathopen {}\left \lvert H\right \rvert \mathclose {}}:\equiv \lambda \_.\mathsf {refl}\right ]\mathclose {}}. What remains of our telescope is the following:
Zooming into the \alpha _H component, we simplify it and then zoom back out:

By dependent homotopy induction (also function extensionality), the remaining data collapse to a point with substitution {\mathopen {}\left [\alpha _g :\equiv \alpha _f; \alpha _H :\equiv \lambda \_.\mathsf {refl}\right ]\mathclose {}}. The remaining telescope is empty, so we are done.

One of the most common tasks when working in univalent foundations is to characterize the path space of a given type, i.e. establish a structure identity principle. Formalized SIP proofs often follow a baroque style involving identity systems and the even more complex displayed identity systems, etc. that sometimes obscure the very simple informal reasoning behind a given structure identity principle; the proposal is to develop a formal proof language to better reflect this informal reasoning, backed by a suite of lemmas and tactics.
To understand what I mean, let us consider how we might characterize the path spaces of morphisms in a co-slice A\downarrow \mathcal {U}.

Let A be a type; an A-algebra X is defined to be a type {\mathopen {}\left \lvert X\right \rvert \mathclose {}} equipped with a function {A}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _A}}{{\mathopen {}\left \lvert X\right \rvert \mathclose {}}}. A homomorphism {X}\xrightarrow {{f}}{Y} of A-algebras is defined to be a function {{\mathopen {}\left \lvert X\right \rvert \mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left \lvert f\right \rvert \mathclose {}}}}{{\mathopen {}\left \lvert Y\right \rvert \mathclose {}}} together with a homotopy \alpha _f \colon {\mathopen {}\left \lvert f\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\circ \alpha _X \sim \alpha _Y. A homotopy H\colon f\sim g between homomorphisms {X}\xrightarrow {{f,g}}{Y} is given by a homotopy {\mathopen {}\left \lvert H\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\colon {\mathopen {}\left \lvert f\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\sim {\mathopen {}\left \lvert g\right \rvert \mathclose {}} together with an assignment to each a:A of an identification \alpha _H a\colon {\mathopen {}\left \lvert H\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\alpha _X a \cdot \eta _g a = \eta _f a.

The goal is always to contract a telescope to a point, and each step is either a rearrangement of the telescope, a “zooming in” step that adjusts a component of the telescope, or an application of some form of identity induction to kill off part of the telescope — path induction, homotopy induction, equivalence induction, etc. In general, we want to be able to easily point out the fragment of a telescope that contracts to a point, and then use the resulting substitution to modify the telescope and proceed further until the entire telescope is gone.
